#Text=Black
#Text=Caesar ( pirate )
#Text=For the 19th century Haitian pirate , see Henri Caesar .
#Text=Black Caesar
#Text=( died 1718 ) was a legendary 18th-century African pirate .

#Text=The lengends say that for nearly a decade , he raided shipping from the Florida Keys and later served as one of Captain Blackbeard ' s , a.k.a. Edward Teach 's , crewmen aboard the Queen Anne 's Revenge .
#Text=He was one of the surviving members of Blackbeard 's crew following his death at the hands of Lieutenant Robert Maynard in 1718 .
#Text=Caesar 's Rock
#Text=, one of three islands located north of Key Largo , is named in his honor , [ 1 ] and is the present-day site of his original headquarters .
#Text=However , there is no historical evidence to support Caesar 's existence .
#Text=Biography according to legend
#Text=Black Caesar , according to traditional accounts , was a prominent African tribal war chieftain .
#Text=Widely known for his " huge size , immense strength and keen intelligence , " he evaded capture from many different slave traders .

column1: #Text=Caesar was finally captured when he and twenty of his warriors were lured onto a ship by a slave trader .
#Text=Showing him a watch , the trader promised to show him and his warriors more objects , which were " too heavy and too numerous to bring on shore " if they came aboard his ship .
#Text=He enticed them to stay with food , musical instruments , silk scarves and jewels , however he had his men raise anchor and slowly sail away .
#Text=When Caesar discovered what was happening , he and his men attempted to charge their captors but were driven back by the well-armed sailors using swords and pistols .

#Text=Although it took a considerable length of time for him and his warriors to accept their captivity , he was eventually befriended by a sailor who was the only man Black Caesar would accept food and water from .
#Text=As they neared the coast of Florida , the sudden appearance of a hurricane threatened to destroy the ship on the Florida Reefs .
#Text=Recognizing the ship 's imminent destruction , the sailor snuck below decks and freed Caesar .
#Text=The two then forced the captain and crew into a corner , most likely at gunpoint , and boarded one of the longboats with ammunition and other supplies .
#Text=The wind and waves pushed them to shore where they waited out the storm , apparently the only survivors of the doomed ship .
#Text=They soon began using the lifeboat to lure passing ships which stopped to give assistance .
#Text=While posing as shipwrecked sailors , they would sail out to the vessel offering to take them aboard .
#Text=Once they were close to the vessel , they brought out their guns and demanded supplies and ammunition , threatening to sink the ship if they were refused .
#Text=He and the sailor continued this ploy for a number of years and amassed a sizable amount of treasure which was buried on Elliott Key . [ 2 ]
#Text=However , he and the sailor had a falling out over a young woman the mate had brought back from one of the ships they had looted .
#Text=Fighting over her , Caesar killed his longtime friend in a duel and took the woman for his own .
#Text=He began taking on more pirates over time and soon was able to attack ships on the open sea .
#Text=He and his crew were often able to avoid capture by running into Caesar Creek and other inlets between Elliot and Old Rhodes Key and onto the mangrove islands .
#Text=Using a metal ring embedded in a rock , they ran a strong rope through the ring , heel the boat over , and hide their boat in the water until the patrol ship or some other danger went away .
#Text=They might also lower the mast and sink the ship in shallow water , later cutting the rope or pumping out the water to raise the boat and continue raiding .
#Text=It is thought that he and his men buried 26 bars of silver on the island , although no treasure has ever been recovered from the island .
#Text=He apparently had a harem on his island , having at least 100 women seized from passing ships , as well as a prison camp which he kept prisoners in stone huts hoping to ransom them .
#Text=When leaving the island to go on raids , he left no provisions for these prisoners and many eventually starved to death .
#Text=A few children reportedly escaped captivity , subsisting on berries and shellfish , and formed their own language and customs .
#Text=This society of lost children gave rise to native superstition that the island is haunted .

#Text=During the early 18th century , Caesar left Biscayne Bay to join Blackbeard in raiding American shipping in the Mid-Atlantic serving as a lieutenant on his flagship Queen Anne 's Revenge . [ 3 ]
#Text=In 1718 , after Blackbeard 's death battling with Lieutenant Robert Maynard at Ocracoke Island , he attempted to set off the powder magazine as per Blackbeard 's instructions .
#Text=However , Caesar was stopped by one of the captives who tackled him as he prepared to light a trail of gunpowder leading to the magazine .

#Text=He struggled with the man below decks until several of Maynard 's sailors were able to restrain him . Taken prisoner by Virginian colonial authorities , he was convicted of piracy and hanged in Williamsburg , Virginia . [ 4 ]
#Text=In popular culture

#Text=The descendants of Caesar and his crew are depicted in Albert Payson Terhune ' s 1922 novel Black Caesar 's Clan which describes people living near Caesar 's Creek who chase off treasure hunters looking for Caesar 's lost fortune .
#Text=Jimmy Akingbola
#Text=played Black Caesar in the 2005 mini series Blackbeard : Terror at Sea .
#Text=In the 2006 film Blackbeard , Black Caesar is depicted by Christopher Clyde-Green as a Boatswain on Blackbeard 's ship .
